section.name: Destination-based sales tax. Overriding vendor's tax calculation method.
section.p: Keywords: destination-based vs origin-based sales tax.
section.h4: Destination-based sales tax. Overriding vendor's tax calculation method.
section.p: If law of your country allows to use different sales tax calculation methods, then you can set Tax destination method for vendors with different methods. For example you use HALF-UP rounding and item basis method, but a vendor uses HALF-DOWN and invoice basis, then just create Tax destination with different methods and set it in this vendor. You are also able to change sales tax amount in invoice line (item basis) or in invoice total (invoice basis).

If sales taxes in your country depend of a region (state, province, county, etc., e.g. this applies in USA), then you should add Tax destination for that region and set it in customers (from that region), then add Item tax category with destination sales taxes, then add Tax destination line (tax destination-destination tax category) for selling items. When you sell such items to "other destination customers", then "destination taxes" will be used instead of tax category of item (origin taxes).

Assume, Bob has sold same items to two customers - Mini-mart from New York, FSC from other state. Taxable items in NY (aggregate rate, item basis, half-up):
Cheese, STG4.7%, STG6.4%
Armchair, STG4.7%, STG6.4%
Sofa, STG4.7%, STG6.4%
Delivering, STS11%
Taxable items in other state (aggregate rate, invoice basis, half-down):
Cheese, STF2.7%, STF3.17%, STF1.234%
Armchair, non taxable
Sofa, origin taxable
Delivering, STF11%
Price inclusive of taxes for both cases.
